newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Volvo says nightwork ban not to hit Nedcar output.
newsitem.headline: Volvo says nightwork ban not to hit Nedcar output.

text.p: Swedish automotive group Volvo said on Thursday a Dutch government ban on a permanent night shift at its co-owned Nedcar plant would not put production targets at risk.
"The news is not a threat either to the profitability of the S40/V40 (car series) or to the production target of 65,000 cars set up for this year," Volvo spokesman Ingemar Hesslefors told Reuters.

Nedcar, a joint venture between Volvo Car, Mitsubishi Motors Corp and the Dutch government, said earlier it had failed to get a permit from the ministry of social affairs to introduce night shifts, which could have boosted production hours by one quarter.
The company aims to increase production to 280,000 cars in 1998 from a planned output of 145,000 in 1996.

"What Nedcar applied for was to introduce a permanent night shift where the workers would continuously work nights. There is still the possibility of introducing a night shift with a rolling schedule," Hesslefors.
Discussions would now begin between Nedcar's management and the works council, Hesslefors said.
"Now that we've reached the end of the road with one alternative, we'll have to solve things with prevailing legislation," Hesslefors said.

Nedcar earlier this month applied for a licence to introduce nightshifts, saying it was vital for the company to increase its production by a quarter to 5,000 hours annually to meet its output target.

The ministry of social affairs said it would not give the permit to start a permanent nightshift in the Nedcar plant in the southern town of Born, as it was against the law to accept more than 28 nightshifts in 13 weeks.
